60 WebStorm/IntelliJ IDE Tips, Tricks, and Features That Will Make Your Life Easier

ref https://medium.com/litslink/webstorm-intellij-ide-tips-tricks-and-features-that-will-make-your-life-easier-6d0c38ff3d4b
ÊÑüËßâÂ≠¶Âà∞‰∫ÜÂ•Ω‰∫õÊñ∞ÁöÑ intelJ ÈÖçÁΩÆ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇ„ÄÇÊÑüËßâÊå∫Â•Ω

In this article we will talk about capabilities, tip and features of JetBrains IDEs like Webstorm and Intellij that you get out of the box but 90% chance that you don‚Äôt use it.

For our examples, I will use a simple Typescript React project created by create-react-app script and simple TS files for tests like 2 + 2 = 4.

1. Presentation plugin

Before we will begin our journey I will install a Presentation plugin‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶that will show us notifications with the action name and shortcuts for iOS/Win/Linux:

2. Find in files

We will start with a simple Find in files feature [**Shift+Command+F**]. It allows you to search any text fragments everywhere in your Project:

3. Replace in files

[Shift+Command+R]

This feature allows you to rename all fragments that match the search.

You can just click Replace All and IDE will rename each and every variable that will be in the list. You need to be careful with using Replace All especially if you‚Äôre not using Git.

4. Find usages

[Option+F7]

Find usages will show you places where current function/class/variable is used:

5. Find usage in File

[Shift+F7]

IDE will highlight all appearances in the current file and highlights will remain until you press **ESC** key:

6. Find next / Move to next Occurrence

You can move to the next occurrence with Find Next/Move to next occurrence action by selecting what you need to search and pressing **Command+G** hotkey:

7. Go to declaration or usages

You don‚Äôt need to use your mouse for finding Usages, just use [Command+B] hotkey:

8. Go to Class:

If you are looking for a class in your project you can use [Command+O] hotkey

If you don‚Äôt remember the name of your class, you can try to search by Name fragments:

If you know the specific code line you need to check you can use a dots : notation ‚Üí <file name>:<codeline number> and IDE will redirect you directly there:

If you are at the Classes navigation press Commad + O again to search everywhere, including Project‚Äôs libraries/packages folders, I will look for types and interfaces too:

9. Go to File

[Shift+Command+O]

This option will search for a files, in this case it doesn‚Äôt matter what is in there:

10. Go to Folder

[Shift+Command+O]

If you will type a slash symbol before the searched name /SomeFolderName. IDE will search only folders, files will be excluded from a search result list:

11. Go to Symbol

[Option+Command+O]

This feature allows your search for functions and fields that are declared in a specific class name <ClassName>.<FunctionName>. It will show all hello functions and fields of a FirstClass or FirstClass TS files:

12. Search everywhere anything

[Double Shift]

This is the most powerful feature of JetBrains IDEs. It allows a developer to do almost anything:

  • search class/files/folders;
  • run scripts (will show later in this story);
  • open preferences tabs;
  • change theme;
  • open menus/popups (will show later in this story)
  • etc‚Ä¶

Functionality is almost limitless.

13. Navigate through search history

If you press [Option+Up/Down] keys inside ‚ÄúSearch everywhere‚Äù you can navigate through your search history:

14. Problems window. Highlighted Errors navigation

You don‚Äôt need scroll down when you are looking for errors in your code. Just use the [ **F2** ] key and IDE will scroll to the Next Highlighted Error:

Previous Highlighted Error ‚Üí [ **Shift+F2** ]

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: IDE will only navigate you through errors, not formatting issues. You can click at the top-right icon‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ or press [ **Command+6** ] for showing the ‚ÄúProblems‚Äù window:

15. Run scripts after search

You can even run commands from a search bar, **npm start** for example. Or maybe you have a test you want to run, you can do that without opening your tests file. But you must remember that you can run only that files/tests/scripts that were previously added to the IDE configuration scripts:

Take a look at how it works:

You can even commit your changes by typing commit:

üëç So, as you can see ‚ÄúSearch Everywhere‚Äù action allows you to not just find something, but execute as well.

16. Commit without ‚Äúadd‚Äù

IDE is smart enough to tell you that you have ‚ÄúUnversioned files‚Äù and you need to add them first before the commit, but‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ you can add ‚ÄúUnversioned files‚Äù you can add them in the ‚ÄúCommit changes‚Äù window by clicking the checkbox:

!]can just click [**Control+Option+O** / ‚åÉ‚å•O] and IDE will do that for you

19. VCS Operations

You can open the VCS (Version Control System) menu by pressing [**Control+V** ], so you don‚Äôt have to remember all VCS commands like commit , push , etc‚Ä¶

20. Open in a split tab

You can open the searched file in a new Tab by clicking **Enter**, or you can open the searched file in a split tab if you press **Shift+Enter** :

21. Evaluate mathematical expressions

In the ‚ÄúSearch everywhere‚Äù window you can quickly type and evaluate simple mathematical expressions.

You can use basic arithmetic operators ‚Äî +, -, *, /, as well as ^ for power ‚Äî and basic math functions: sqrt(), sin(), cos(), tan().

22. File structure

Probably you noticed Structure window that you can show/hide by clicking on it or by pressing [ **Command+7** ] keys:

But the cool thing is that you can open it without messing with your editor tabs in a popup window by pressing [ **Command+F12** ] hotkey:

23. See recent files

If your search input field is empty, ‚ÄúSearch everywhere‚Äù will show your recent files:

You can see exactly the same list by using [ **Command+E**/ ‚åòE] hotkey ‚Üí Recent Files window will show up.

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: If you delete recent files from this list, they will be gone from the recent list of a **Search Everywhere** too

Recent Files will show you only changed files if you press [ Command+E / ‚åòE ] hotkey:

24. Structural search and replace

WebStorm treats your code as regular text. The structural search and replace (SSR) actions let you search for a particular code pattern

WebStorm finds and replaces fragments of source code, based on the search templates that you create and conditions you apply.

This feature is very useful when you need to refactor the code structure.

Select Edit > Find > **Search Structurally** from the main menu, or just type the required name in the ‚ÄúSearch everywhere‚Äù window:

It will open the Structural Search window:

You can use Existing Templates predefined in IDE by clicking on settings icon:

You can edit those templates and save them as your own:

You can check the history of your changes by clicking the **search** icon:

Here I will show you a simple example because Structural Search uses its own syntax (I will tell more about it next time).

Let‚Äôs imaging that we have empty functions defined in our code, and search by text will not help you find all of them:

We can define our search template‚Ä¶

const $name$ = ($parameter$) => {

}

‚Ä¶and replace template:

const $name$ = ($parameter$) => {
// TODO: This should be fixed, or removed
}

IDE will highlight elements that match this pattern. Click ‚ÄúFind‚Äù:

‚ÄòFind Window‚Äô will be shown after the ‚ÄòFind‚Äô click. You can check if all results are correct. After that, you can click Replace All (don‚Äôt recommend this approach, especially if you are not using VCS) or Replace Selected:

Also, you can ‚ÄòPreview Replacement‚Äô that will show you what your code fragment will look like after replacement:

You probably noticed that we made a mistake when we specified replace template. It will use only use parameter name but will exclude the parameter‚Äôs type.

But for educational purposes, I will click ‚ÄúReplace All‚Äù üôÇ. Let‚Äôs see what we will get:

Now at least we have TODO markers in our Project that say to us that we should do something about it.

25. Adding a custom hotkey

As you noticed there are no hotkeys assigned to the ‚ÄúStructural search and replace‚Äù, let‚Äôs change that. Open IDE preferences Command+, and type structural in the preference‚Äôs search field, find Search Structurally‚Ä¶and click the Right button:

Just type keys you want to use and press **Ok**.

If there will be collisions with some other hotkeys, don‚Äôt worry, IDE will tell you about it:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: Don‚Äôt try to type keys separately from each other like Control, Option, S. It will not work that way. Just use a combination like you are trying to use it already, like [Control+Option+S ] hotkey.

26. Macros

Macros provide a convenient way to automate repetitive procedures you do frequently while writing code. You can record, edit, and playback macros, assign a shortcut to them, and share them.

You can start recording by clicking **Edit>Macros>Start Macro Recording**, but I will do it by typing start macro in Search everything

You will see a pop-up with a **STOP** button:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: When you are creating Macros, IDE will record only your actions, but it will not record autocompletion and auto imports. So before you Record a really big code fragment (which I don‚Äôt recommend, use templates instead), try it with something simple and by adding features step-by-step.

Let‚Äôs create something awesome‚Ä¶ When you finished, click **STOP** icon and select a name for your Macro.

export const sum = (a: string, b: string) => { return a + b;
}

I will delete all I have created in the file and click on **Play Back Last Macro**:

27. Language injection

We all had such cases when we need to type a simple text that should represent JSON, RegEx, HTML, SQL, etc. You don‚Äôt need to create those files so that IDE would help you. You can use Language Injection so that IDE would handle those Language fragments in a simple string:

In ES6 JavaScript you can use template literals `{‚Äúname‚Äù: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äù}`, but in this example, we will pretend that we are still using ES5 üôÇ

Now IDE will highlight our JSON props and will notify us if we made a mistake:

‚ÄòEdit JSON fragment‚Äô action will open a JSON editor:

Now let‚Äôs take a look at how it works in IDE:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: If you don‚Äôt see **Edit JSON Fragment** in Context Actions ‚Äî make sure that you have Editor > Intensions >Edit injected fragment enabled:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: All previous examples were temporary injections, they will reset if you restart the IDE, if you want to set this injection permanently you will need to add a comment above the string:

// language=JSON

‚Ä¶ or you can just answer ‚ÄúYes‚Äù when IDE will ask you üôÇ

Same with RegExp:

Now you will be able to test your regex in the popup window:

28. Live Templates

Just like with Macros Live Templates provide a powerful feature of creating your own templates of any code you like, variable/ function/ class/ component/ package declarations.

You can see available predefined templates by using [ Command+J / ‚åòJ] hotkey:

You can create your own templates, just search ‚ÄòLive Templates‚Äô in IDE preferences:

Let‚Äôs take o look at some simple example:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: Don‚Äôt forget to set the Applicable context so that your templates were shown by IDE only in files that can use those templates (I don‚Äôt think that the Jest test fragment should be shown in SQL üôÇ):

After applying new templates you can use them by typing your custom abbreviation:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: You can edit IDE‚Äôs predefined templates as well.

29. Enable preview tab

The preview tab allows you to view files in a single tab one by one without opening each file in a new tab. Any other file that you select will replace the previous one in this tab.

You can enable this feature in the IDE Preferences:

Or here in the Project window settings:

Now you can preview files without opening them in a new tab by just clicking one time on a file, if you click twice ‚Äî file will be opened in an old-fashioned way.

30. Quick preview

If you don‚Äôt want to enable the ‚ÄòPreview Tab‚Äô feature you can just press Space key and IDE will show you the content of the file in a pop-up window without opening any tabs:

31. Always select opened file

If this option is on, WebStorm automatically locates documents that you open in the editor in the current view of this window.

32. Jump to Navigation bar

This feature is useful when you don‚Äôt use the NavBar at the top of the IDE:

You can disable it in View > Appearance > ‚úîÔ∏é Navigation Bar, but note that the toolbar will disappear too:

You just need to enable it after disabling the Navigation Bar:

The point is that your workplace will become cleaner and you could just invoke it only when you needed by using [ Command+Up / ‚åò‚Üë] hotkeys ‚ÄúJump to Navigation Bar‚Äù action:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: You can use the ‚ÄòShow Source‚Äô action by pressing [ Command+Enter ] hotkey that will show you selected folder in the Project window or create a new File/Folder inside of selected folder by pressing [Command+N] hotkey

33. Editor tabs

If you like working with Tabs enabled, you can place your tab in the Top/ Left/ Bottom/ Right or None. Let‚Äôs set the placement to the Left:

It will have some benefits, now your tabs will not mess up with names and you will see the whole list with the full names:

Or you can just disable them and use ‚ÄúRecent files‚Äù -> [ Command+E ] hotkey‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ and navigating through the Project window only. You can hide/show it by using [Command+1 / ‚åò1] hotkey:

You can switch between the Project and Editor tab only with ‚åò1 and ESC, let‚Äôs take a look how it works:

34. Create a new file

If you want to create a new file inside a folder you can just select a folder in which you want to create a file or select a file in that folder and press [Command+N / ‚åòN] hotkey:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: If you want to create a file inside folders you can create it by separate folders with use of a a slash: folder1/folder2/folder3/**File.ts**:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: If you open a file for editing, and you want to create a new file inside of a current folder you can use the ‚ÄòNew in This Directory‚Äô action [Control+Option+N / ‚åÉ‚å•N] hotkey:

35. Create file template

You can create your own File Templates so that when you ‚ÄòCreate new file‚Äô your own template will be in that list.

Search for the file and code templates in ‚ÄòSearch everywhere‚Äô window:

Or find it in IDE‚Äôs Preferences window:

After creating your template, when you use ‚ÄúNew in this directory‚Äù you will see your own template, and you can specify additional props values:

üéâ Awesome.

36. Hide all windows

If you use [ Shift+Command+F12 / ‚áß‚åòF12] hotkey ‚Üí it will hide all opened windows except the editor window, if you press the hotkey again ‚Üí it will restore all hidden windows:

37. Resize active window

You can resize the active window without using a mouse: Stretch to Right/Letf by using [Shift+Command+Left/Right] hotkey:

38. Select and move lines

Most of the time we need to move lines from one place in code to another. Stop using copy-paste actions. You can select lines by pressing [Shift+Up/Down] hotkey:

‚Ä¶ and after that press Option, so your combination would become [Shift+Option+Up/Down] and move lines in the current file:

39. Move statement

If you want to move a function you can just use ‚ÄúMove statement‚Äù action by pressing Shift + Command + Up/Down. In that case IDE will move a function without selecting it:

40. Select line, fragment, function, class, package

What if you want to select a specific code fragment, maybe a part of a function, or some props or a class or entire package? You can do that by using ‚ÄúExtend/Shrink Selection‚Äù action by pressing Option + Up/Down:

41. Clipboard history

How many times you missed your keys and instead of using [Command+V] (copy) after [Command+X] (cut), you used [Command+X] again? ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇ

In that case, you will lose your Clipboard history, but not if you are using JetBrains IDEs üôÇ.

If you used [Command+X] twice you can press [Shift+Command+V] and IDE will show you all your Copy/Cut history you used:

42. Duplicate a line/selection

If you want to create a copy of a code fragment you don‚Äôt need to use Copy/Paste functionality, you can just use the ‚ÄúDuplicate Line‚Äù action by [Command+D] hotkey:

If will perfectly work for selections too:

43. Multiple cursors by mouse click

You can set multiple cursors by pressing Option/Alt key with the Mouse click:

44. Multiple cursors by next Occurrence

[Control+Command+G] hotkey will select only next Occurrence. This is definitely will be in handy:

Check this out:

45. Multiple cursors. Select All Occurrences

[Control+Command+G] hotkey will set multiple cursors at every occurrence in the code:

46. Parameter info

If you forgot what params you need to pass to the function, you don‚Äôt need to delete brackets and set them again.

You can just use the [Command+P] hotkey

47. Reformat code

You can reformat all file by using the ‚ÄúReformat code‚Äù action via [Option+Command+L] hotkey.

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: If you want to reformat only specific lines you can select required lines and use the ‚ÄúAuto-Indent lines‚Äù action via [Control+Option+I] hotkey:

You can open ‚ÄòCode cleanup‚Äô preferences by searching code cleanup in the Search everywhere:

!Bog`, and IDE will suggest with a completion list:

52. Surround with

‚ÄòSurround With‚Äô popup will appear when you use [Option+Command+T] hotkey:

53. Create constructor, getters, setters, override methods

If you created a class with some fields, you don‚Äôt need to create constructors, getters, setters, override methods manually ‚Üí IDE could do that for you:

[ Command+N ] or [ Control+Enter ]:

All this is generated:

54. Postfix code completion

Postfix code completion helps you reduce backward caret jumps as you write code. You can transform an already-typed expression to a different one based on a postfix you type after the dot, the type of expression, and its context.

List of available completions for user prop:

You can create your own completions in the IDE Preferences:

55. Show quick documentation

You can see the documentation in the popup window by using F1 key:

Quick Documentation action screenshot

56. Refactor this

You don‚Äôt need to remember all IDE Refactor hotkeys, you can just use [Control+T] hotkey for showing all available refactor actions, and you can use them right away:

57. Run the current file

If you have a test file, you can run all tests in it by using [Control+Shift+R] hotkey:

58. Scratch files

Sometimes you may need to create temporary notes or draft up some code outside of the project context. Instead of switching to a different application for this purpose, you can use scratch files and scratch buffers.

You can run them just like if they were included in the Project:

59. Creating your own menu list

If you navigate to IDE‚Äôs Preferences > Quick Lists, you could add your own menu with actions you like the most:

After creating you list, navigate to the Keymap, search for your list name, and assign a new Keyboard Shortcut:

Now you will be able to invoke your list by using your shortcut:

60. Keymap reference

If you want to see all available hotkey in your IDE, or you forgot some of them, you can search for Keymap reference in the ‚ÄòSearch everywhere‚Äô:

It will open a PDF file with all available hotkeys and actions:

Related storiesasic Code Completion‚Äô at it will provide you a list of a proper variable name, [ Control+Space ] hotkey:

49. Code completion. Basic completion

‚ÄòBasic Completion‚Äô will show you all available functions and variables you can use for completion, [ Control+Space ] hotkey:

50. Code completion. Smart completion

Smart Completion will analyze your code and will narrow down the suggestion list to what makes sense, [ Control+Shift+Space ] hotkey:

51. Code completion without a ref

If you want to type a console.log you can just type `l](https://miro.medium.com/max/2528/1*9nNZEwlOHG-WSc4ATTphpQ.jpeg)

You can change code style in those Preferences:

‚ö†Ô∏è NOTE: You can adjust code styles interactively by selecting your code fragment and select ‚Äò_Adjust code style setting_‚Äô in the ‚Äò_Show Context Actions_‚Äô, [Option+Enter] hotkey:

Let‚Äôs have a look at how it works in the IDE:

GIF. Adjust Code Style Settings dynamically

48. Code completion. Variable name

If you want to rename a variable you can use a ‚Äò[(https://miro.medium.com/max/4408/1*zTLGb_2OZA_GgRwQumxtdg.jpeg)

If you click a file in a ‚ÄúCommit changes‚Äù window, IDE will open a Compare Changelist window, where you can review changes and even exclude parts of code that should not be committed:

IDE will show you the changed checkbox icon with the number of committed changes:

17. Run menu

Every file, test, script you run IDE adds those into its configurations (if you saved those they will be available after IDE restart):

‚Ä¶ for saving configuration use Edit Configuration > Save Configuration icon:

But the cool thing is that you can open a pop-up window with all your saved configurations by pressing Control+Option+R and run them without navigating elsewhere:

18. Optimize imports

You don‚Äôt have to manually delete unused imports from your file:

useDarkMode hook :

A closer look

I want to call out a few things about the hook itself that made things work well from a TypeScript perspective. First, let‚Äôs clear out all the extra stuff and just look at the important bits. We‚Äôll even clear out the TypeScript and add it iteratively:

From the get-go, we‚Äôve got an error when calling setMode:

This expression is not callable.
Not all constituents of type ‚Äòstring | React.Dispatch<SetStateAction>‚Äô are callable.
Type ‚Äòstring‚Äô has no call signatures.(2349)
You can read each addition of indentation as ‚Äúbecause‚Äù, so let‚Äôs read that again:

Ëøô‰∏™Ë°®ËææÂºè‰∏çÊòØÂèØË¢´Ë∞ÉÁî®ÁöÑ. Because not all constituents of type ‚Äòstring | React.Dispatch<SetStateAction>‚Äô are callable. Âõ†‰∏∫Êé®Êñ≠Âá∫Êúâ‰ø©ÂÄº,ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÊòØ string ‰∏çÂèØË∞ÉÁî®(2349)

Êàë‰ª¨ËÇâÁúºÂèØËßÅ setMode ÊòØ‰∏™ÂáΩÊï∞,‰∏∫Âï• ts Êé®Êñ≠ÂÆÉÊòØ‰∏§ÁßçÁ±ªÂûã?

Âú®ËøôÁßçÊÉÖÂΩ¢‰∏ã array Êúâ‰ª•‰∏ãÊé®Êñ≠:

Array<string | React.Dispatch<React.SetStateAction<string>>>

TypeScript Ëá™Â∑±Êé®Êñ≠‰∏çÂá∫Êù•Êï∞ÁªÑÁöÑÂÖàÂêéÈ°∫Â∫è,ÂÆÉÂè™Áü•ÈÅìÊï∞ÁªÑËøîÂõû‰∫Ü‰∏™ string Âíå Dispatch Á±ªÂûã

But React‚Äôs useState hook manages to ensure when we extract values out of it. Let‚Äôs take a quick look at their type definition for useState:

Ah, so they have a return type that is an array with explicit types. So rather than an array of elements that can be one of two types, it‚Äôs explicitly an array with two elements where the first is the type of state and the second is a Dispatch SetStateAction for that type of state.

Êàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÂëäËØâ TypeScript Êàë‰ª¨Á°Æ‰øùÊï∞ÁªÑ‰∏ç‰ºöÊîπÂèò.

Or we could make a specific type for a variable:

Êõ¥Â•ΩÁöÑÊñπÂºè ÊòØ Typescript ÂÜÖÂª∫‰∫ÜËøô‰∏™ËÉΩÂäõ,Âõ†‰∏∫ typescript Â∑≤ÁªèÁü•ÈÅì‰∫Ü array ÁöÑÁ±ªÂûã.ÊâÄ‰ª•Êàë‰ª¨Âè™ÈúÄË¶ÅÂëäËØâ ts ‚ÄúËøîÂõûÊï∞ÊçÆÊòØ‰∏çÂèòÁöÑ‚Äù Êàë‰ª¨ÊåáÂÆöËøîÂõûÂÄº‰∏∫ const

ËøôÊ†∑Êàë‰ª¨Â∞±‰∏çÈúÄË¶Å ts Ëá™Â∑±Âà§Êñ≠ËøîÂõûÁ±ªÂûã

And we can take it a step further because with our Dark Mode functionality, the string can be either dark or light so we can do better than TypeScript‚Äôs inference and pass the possible values explicitly:

This will help us when we call setMode to ensure we not only call it with a string, but the right type of string. I also created type aliases for this and the dispatch function to make the prop types easier as I pass these values around my app.

Áù°Ëßâ

ÊàëÁªèÂ∏∏Âú®ÂáåÊô® 1 ÁÇπÊàñ 2 ÁÇπËµ∑Â∫äÔºåÂè™ÊòØÂê¨Âê¨Èü≥‰πêÔºåÁé©Áé©ËßÜÈ¢ëÊ∏∏ÊàèÔºåÁúãÁúã NetflixÔºåÊàñËÄÖ‰∏ä‰∏äÁΩë„ÄÇÊàë‰πüÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰π†ÊÉØÊÄßÊâìÁõπÁöÑ‰∫∫ÔºåÈÄöÂ∏∏Âú®Êó©‰∏äËÆæÁΩÆ 3 ‰∏™ÈóπÈíü„ÄÇÁé∞Âú®ÊàëÊúâ‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÊù°ËßÑÂàô:

  • In bed by midnight
  • Don‚Äôt snooze - wake up to the first alarm

ËøôÂæàÈöæ,‰ΩÜÊàëÁü•ÈÅìÊØèÊ¨°ÊàëËøôÊ†∑ÁîüÊ¥ªÔºå‰∫ãÊÉÖÈÉΩ‰ºöÂèòÂæóÊõ¥Â•Ω„ÄÇÊúâÊó∂ÂÄôÔºå‰Ω†‰∏çÂæó‰∏çÂÅöÈÇ£‰∫õÂú®ÂΩì‰∏ãÁ≥üÁ≥ïÁöÑ‰∫ãÊÉÖÔºå‰∏∫‰∫Ü‰ªäÂêéÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂ§©/‰∏ÄÂë®/‰∏Ä‰∏™Êúà/‰∏ÄÂπ¥/‰∏ÄÂπ¥/‰∏ÄÁîü„ÄÇ

Track net worth

I‚Äôve been tracking my net worth for several years now. I see a lot of people budget month-to-month, but I like seeing the big picture. I just add up all my assets (checking/savings accounts, retirement accounts, stocks, crypto) and debts (credit cards, car loans, phone payments, student loans). Yes, that means if you have no retirement accounts or money in the bank and you owe $100,000 on student loans, your net worth is negative. I don‚Äôt like having any debt, so this helped me early on in my life to pay off all my student loans, and buy a cheap car with cash, and so on.

I just made my own custom Google Sheets page and I input all the numbers at the end of every month. So this is a ‚Äúonce a month‚Äù habit as opposed to some of the other ‚Äúonce a day‚Äù ones.

Learning and practice

I haven‚Äôt necessarily felt the most amount of focus in my life. Art and music don‚Äôt come as naturally to me as they used to. Although I want to practice music, for example, and learn new songs and how to sight read music, I don‚Äôt always feel the motivation to do so. Nonetheless, I‚Äôve set up a daily thing to do - in this case, 10 minutes of sheet music flash card practice. It has the dual benefit of being a more productive thing to do while waiting in line somewhere than scrolling through the news or reddit, and I‚Äôll be that much ahead when I do decide to sit down and learn a song.

So basically it was more productive for me to say ‚ÄúPractice sheet music 10 minutes a day‚Äù than ‚ÄúLearn this song‚Äù which is bigger and requires more upfront effort. And requires me to do something that isn‚Äôt coding related, which is where I‚Äôll naturally gravitate for hobby purposes.

Do the annoying thing immediately

There is nothing I hate more than dealing with bureaucracy. Paying bills by mail when I can‚Äôt do it any other way, calling up any sort of automated system, stuff like that. I usually put off very simple tasks like paying a bill or renewing car insurance for weeks or months, and it‚Äôs always sitting in the back of my mind as something I know I need to do but I really, really don‚Äôt want to.

I‚Äôm personally making an effort to put those on my daily to-do list and just getting them done. It‚Äôs so much better than sitting there and knowing there‚Äôs an annoying thing to do for weeks on end.

Daily journaling

Recently, Matthew McConaughey was on the JRE podcast(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BBCl9A9NlRw) and talked about how he has kept a journal every day for basically his entire life. This is something I‚Äôve never been able to do - I‚Äôve just kind of been going through it day by day and living life in the moment. But there was some great advice there - when things are good, keep track of what‚Äôs going well. When things are bad, see all the factors of what was going on in your life during those times as well.

At least for myself, I occasionally have bouts where life just isn‚Äôt going the way I want, and I feel anxious and depressed seemingly out of nowhere. Then at other times, everything is going great, and I don‚Äôt know why. How much of it is within my control? How much is from external factors? Without having really kept track of anything that‚Äôs going on in my life, it‚Äôs really hard to say.

I‚Äôm aiming to adopt this strategy myself now. I can say things are going pretty well for me right now. I feel good at the moment, even with all the political craziness and lockdown and isolation and having a relatively recent breakup. I don‚Äôt feel anxiety or depression, and I feel a lot of positivity, hope, and potential. I know I won‚Äôt be able to write a detailed diary entry every single day of my life, but I‚Äôm making a point to remember to do it relatively often, and when important or interesting things happen.

Conclusion
